makers.displaydate: 1864–1901; born Albi, France; died Château de Malromé, Saint-André-du-Bois, France
makers.displaymaker: Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, 1864–1901; born Albi, France; died Château de Malromé, Saint-André-du-Bois, France

texts.textentryhtml: Published in 1896, Toulouse-Lautrec’s legendary Elles portfolio sympathetically depicts the everyday lives of women in a Parisian brothel in ten color lithographs as well as a cover and this frontispiece. Likewise, Japanese ukiyo-e (Floating World) woodblock prints capture the sensuality of the elegantly dressed courtesans and Kabuki actors of Yoshiwara, the brothel district of Edo (Tokyo) that had distinct parallels to the Montmartre section of Paris made famous by Toulouse-Lautrec’s lithographs. The flat colors, sinuous curves, and elaborately patterned robes of the fashionable young women depicted in Japanese prints inspired modern European artists and designers of the 1880s and 1890s.

caption: Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec (1864–1901; born Albi, France; died Château de Malromé, Saint-André-du-Bois, France), Published by Gustave Pellet (French, 1859–1919), Frontispiece for the portfolio Elles, 1896.
